title: The Morning After Providence - Initial Setup

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells of Rome's churches toll Prime, calling the faithful to morning prayer. Grey light seeps through the windows of the Palazzo di San Marco. Yesterday changed everything—and nothing. The golden light at St. Peter's. Cardinal Albergati kneeling. Rochetaillée's impossible conversion. The letters dispatched to Christian monarchs. And then the sobering reality: Cardinal Orsini withdrawing to mere compliance, the consistory's passive acceptance, Parentucelli's report of subtle obstruction in the Camera, Cardinal Condulmer's festering grievance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: At Ostia, ten ships wait at anchor. Lucia, two-year-old Catalina, and three ladies-in-waiting remain aboard the Santa Catalina, as arranged. Five hundred ninety-one knights—veterans of Granada and the sea journey—await orders. The Constantinople expedition's August deadline presses closer with each passing day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In Rome, the reform hangs by threads of faith and determination. Rochetaillée prepares to depart for Basel as papal messenger. Parentucelli labors against institutional resistance. The Pope has made his grand gesture; now comes the grey work of implementation. Somewhere in the palazzo, Fray Hernando de Talavera has spent the night in prayer, considering Juan's request that he remain in Rome for a year to guide the Pope through the critical implementation period.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning waits.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I assemble all my knights to address them.

encounters.recap: On the morning after the Pope's historic address, Juan faces the complex aftermath of yesterday's miraculous events. While the papal reforms have been announced, institutional resistance remains strong. With his expedition fleet waiting at Ostia and Constantinople's deadline approaching, Juan decides to address his assembled knights.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Word spreads quickly through the knights' quarters. Within the hour, they have assembled in the courtyard of the Palazzo di San Marco—the largest space available that can accommodate nearly six hundred men. They stand in ranks, these veterans of Granada. Many bear the scars of the Reconquista—a missing finger here, a limping gait there, the weathered faces of men who have seen siege and battle. Their white surcoats with red crosses are travel-worn but clean, maintained with the discipline of soldiers who take pride in their appearance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Among them stand the faces Juan knows well: Marco Tornesi, the former mercenary seeking redemption. Andrea Vescovi, the gangly farmer's son who was the first to take the crusader oath in Barcelona four years ago. Giovanni Rossi, the former blacksmith who prays more than anyone. Brother Guillem, the Benedictine monk-warrior. Captain Rodrigo and Sergeant García, who have been with Juan since the beginning. The morning sun catches the red crosses on their chests. Five hundred ninety-one men who followed their king across the sea, witnessed the golden light in St. Peter's, and now wait to learn what comes next.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers, Yesterday, we have witnessed how the pope reformed the church. A truly momentous occasion we have had the privilege to bear witness of. Today we continue our journey east to Constantinople. I have pledged myself to protect the church and in order to protect the pope, I will require some of our number to remain behind. To observe and to signal if anyone decides to take up arms against the holy father. I require about 10 to remain here. You will not remain here forever, just for a while as the church absorbs this change. You will all return to Castille. Brothers! Have a good meal and cast your eyes on Rome for a final time, for we leave in a few hours for Ostia and the ships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur ripples through the assembled knights—not dissent, but the sound of men absorbing news. Constantinople. The name carries weight. They knew this was coming, had known since they boarded ships in Castile, but hearing it spoken aloud makes it real. Marco Tornesi straightens almost imperceptibly, the former mercenary's eyes bright with something that might be anticipation. Andrea Vescovi glances at the men beside him, then back to Juan, his young face solemn. Giovanni Rossi's lips move silently—a prayer, likely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When Juan calls for ten to remain, hands begin to rise. Not eagerly, not reluctantly—with the steady resolve of men who understand duty. More than ten. Perhaps fifteen or eighteen hands.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo
exchanges.text: We'll sort it among ourselves, Your Majesty. Ten good men who can keep their eyes open and their mouths shut.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A rumble of assent from the ranks. Fray Hernando meets Juan's gaze. The Franciscan's weathered face is still, but something passes between them—acknowledgment of the choice being offered, the weight of it. He does not speak. Not here, not before the men. But he inclines his head, very slightly. The conversation will come. Later.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "¡Por Castilla y por Cristo!" someone shouts from the ranks—and five hundred voices take up the cry, echoing off the palazzo walls. "¡Por Castilla y por Cristo!"

encounters.recap: Juan addresses his 591 assembled knights in the courtyard of Palazzo di San Marco, announcing their departure for Constantinople and requesting ten volunteers to remain in Rome as protectors of the Pope during the church reforms. The veterans respond with discipline and loyalty, more than enough volunteering to stay behind.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pope Eugenius IV receives Juan in the same private chamber where they drafted the letter to Basel. The Pope looks tired—the grey exhaustion of a man who slept little after a day of momentous action—but there is steel beneath the weariness that was not there a week ago. Tommaso Parentucelli stands beside him, dark circles under his eyes, ink stains on his fingers. The scholar-administrator has clearly worked through the night.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: A kind gesture. Though ten knights against Rome's factions... We are grateful nonetheless. They will be housed and fed at Vatican expense.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of Cardinal Orsini's cooperation. I would... temper that assessment somewhat. The Cardinal fulfills his obligations. He provides information when asked directly. But he no longer volunteers intelligence. No longer anticipates needs. The difference is subtle but significant.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And Cardinal Condulmer remains in his chambers. My own nephew. He has not spoken to me since yesterday morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises, moving to the window that overlooks the city.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You sail east to aid Constantinople against the Turk. A holy mission. We will pray for your success daily. But understand what you leave behind. The reform has the support of princes and bankers. It has the acquiescence of cardinals who cannot oppose it. What it lacks... What it lacks is men who believe in it. Aside from Parentucelli here, and perhaps Rochetaillée—who departs today for Basel—the reform stands on fear and calculation, not conviction.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I leave it to the pope to appoint those who operate in this reformed church. Who have the conviction we seek. This will take time. Even a thousand knights would not help in this regard. You are secured. If anyone moves against you, Naples and Castille stand ready to come to your aid immediately, and our enemies know this. Our reform has been received very well. Now comes the work to follow up. Maybe the pope will be able to find those servants in Basel. Speak to cardinal Rochetaille before he leaves and ask him for men who can replace who have been tainted by corruption. You have the treasury as well. Guard it and use it if need be to build a new church. Almost everything has been going our way. What remains is just honest work.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Basel. Yes. Perhaps there are men there who hunger for a Church worth serving, not merely a benefice worth holding. Tommaso, before Cardinal Rochetaillée departs—speak with him. Ask him to identify reformers of genuine conviction. Men who can be brought to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Yes, Holiness.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope crosses to Juan and takes his hands—an intimate gesture, monarch to monarch, but also something more. Spiritual father to spiritual son.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You speak wisdom beyond your years, Juan of Castile. 'Honest work.' Yes. That is what remains. We have grown accustomed to miracles these past days. Golden light and impossible conversions. Now comes the grey labor of making those miracles permanent. Benedictio Dei omnipotentis, Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, descendat super te et maneat semper. Go with God to Constantinople. Defend the faith against the Turk as you have defended it against corruption. And return to us safely.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. What you have begun here... I will not let it fail. Whatever it costs.

encounters.recap: Juan bids farewell to Pope Eugenius IV and Tommaso Parentucelli before departing for Constantinople. They discuss the fragile state of the church reform, acknowledging that while secured by fear and calculation, it lacks true believers beyond a few key figures. The Pope blesses Juan's mission and commits to finding genuine reformers from Basel to strengthen their cause.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds Lucia aboard, in the great cabin. Two-year-old Catalina sits on the floor, playing with a wooden horse carved by one of the sailors. She looks up as Juan enters, her face breaking into a smile.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises from where she has been watching their daughter. Her belly has begun to show now—five months along, perhaps six. She moves more carefully than she once did.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Juan. The men say we sail today.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina squeals with delight as Juan lifts her, her small hands reaching for his face. At two years old, she has her mother's dark eyes and a child's boundless curiosity.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Barcos! Agua!

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She has been fascinated by everything. The sailors. The ropes. The seabirds. One of the men—Pascual, I think—carved her that horse. She won't let it out of her sight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Caballo!

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The port... Busy. Roman merchants, mostly. Some looked at our ships with too much interest for my comfort. Doña Beatriz thinks they were merely curious, but... I will be glad when we are at sea again. What happened in Rome? The men speak of golden light and cardinals kneeling. Some say it was a miracle.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He tells her everything. The Mass at St. Peter's—the golden light that poured through the windows as Eugenius spoke, the cardinals who knelt, the 'Deo gratias' that shook the basilica. RochetaillÃ©e's impossible conversion. The letters dispatched to every Christian monarch. And then the rest. Cardinal Orsini's face when Juan pushed too hard. The consistory's passive acceptance without conviction. Parentucelli's reports of subtle obstruction. Cardinal Condulmer nursing his grievance.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: A blacksmith knows when the metal is ready. And when it needs more time at the forge. You have done what you could in Rome. More than anyone expected. More than anyone had a right to ask. But Constantinople is not Rome, Juan. The Turks are not cardinals who can be shamed into kneeling. What waits for us in the East?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds the captain of the Santa Catalina on deck—a weathered Castilian named Diego de Vargas, grey-bearded and sun-darkened from decades at sea.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_vargas
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The exercises. Better than the first day. Not yet what I'd want if the Mistral caught us in open water. We've run the storm drill twice more since you left for the Vatican. The San Marcos and Catalina perform well—Pascual's crew especially. They've taken to the competitions. The converted carracks still struggle. Their crews weren't trained for war or weather—merchant sailors, most of them. They're learning, but... The journey to Naples is short. The journey to Constantinople is not. We'll be ready for Naples by the evening tide, Your Majesty. As for what comes after—we'll keep drilling. Every calm day, every safe harbor. The men understand the stakes now.

encounters.recap: Juan reunites with his family aboard the Santa Catalina in Ostia. He shares the full account of his Roman triumph and setbacks with Lucia, who offers wisdom about the challenges ahead. Captain Diego reports on fleet exercises and readiness for the voyage to Naples, noting improvement but acknowledging the need for more training time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first day passed without incident—fair winds from the north, the fleet making good time along the Italian coast. Catalina delighted in watching the dolphins that played in the Santa Catalina's wake. The carrack crews, drilled relentlessly by their captains, showed signs of improvement. Then, on the morning of the second day, the lookout's cry shattered the calm.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan reaches the deck to find Captain Vargas already at the rail, shading his eyes against the morning glare. Three ships on the southern horizon, their lateen sails unmistakable.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: Corsairs. Out of Tunis or Algiers, most like. Galleys—fast and nimble. They've seen us.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: They won't attack ten ships, Your Majesty—not unless they're mad or desperate. But our carracks are slow. If they shadow us, probe for weakness, catch a straggler... We can hold formation and protect her—but that slows everyone. Or we can signal the warships to chase them off—but that splits the fleet and leaves the carracks vulnerable.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Captain, we form up with the carracks on front, shielding the slower, less defended ships. If they come close, fire the cannons. We are well-armed, let them know that we are looking for a fight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Signal flags run up the mast. Across the fleet, captains respond. The five warships—galleys built for speed and combat—spread into a protective screen. The carracks, heavy and bristling with cannons, form up at the front of the formation, their gun ports open, bronze barrels glinting in the morning sun. The rumble of cannon carriages rolling forward echoes across the water.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The corsair galleys continue their approach for several minutes, closing the distance. Then, as the formation becomes clear—as the morning light catches the cannon barrels and the red crosses on white surcoats lining the rails—the lead galley's oars shift rhythm. They're turning.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: They're not fools. Three galleys against this? They'd take one ship, maybe two, and lose all three in the doing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan brings Catalina to the deck, holding her securely as she points at the distant sails. Her dark eyes are wide with curiosity—at two years old, she does not yet understand danger.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: ¿Barcos, Papá?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No quiero.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She's too young to understand, but not too young to remember. My grandmother used to tell me stories of Barbary raids on the Portuguese coast. Whole villages taken. Children who never saw their parents again. This is why you go to Constantinople. This is why you build ships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The corsairs finally turn away as darkness falls, vanishing into the southern blackness. By morning, the fleet is exhausted. The carrack crews, already inexperienced, have been pushed hard maintaining formation through the night. The fleet limps into Naples under the shadow of Vesuvius.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: We made it, Your Majesty. But if those had been Turkish galleys instead of Tunisian corsairs—faster, better armed, more numerous... The men need rest. The carrack crews need more drilling. And we need to think hard about the route east.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Start training for hostile naval encounters as well captain. I head for the harbour and meet with the master.

roll.outcome: Serious trouble. Corsair sighting forces defensive formation. Fleet limps into Naples with problems to solve.

encounters.recap: Three Barbary corsairs shadow the fleet during the voyage to Naples, forcing a defensive formation with carracks screening the passenger ships. Juan's tactical decision to display cannon strength deters attack, but the night passage exhausts crews and exposes the fleet's vulnerabilities for the longer journey to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The streets of Naples are tense. Armed men in Aragonese colors patrol in groups, watching rooftops and alleyways. Merchants have shuttered early. Women hurry children indoors. The atmosphere is not that of a city preparing for victory—it is the brittle quiet of a city bracing for siege. At the gates of Castel Nuovo, a harried official recognizes the Castilian royal standard and nearly weeps with relief.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the courtyard, wounded men sit against walls, being tended by surgeons. Their bandages are fresh—days old, not weeks. A cluster of knights in battered armor speak in low, angry voices. One has his arm in a sling. Another bears a half-healed gash across his face.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso V of Aragon stands at a table covered with maps, correspondence, and the detritus of desperate planning. He is forty years old, but today he looks older. His clothes are fine but rumpled, as though he dressed without the aid of servants. Dark circles rim his eyes. His jaw is shadowed with several days' growth.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Juan. You've heard, then.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I heard de Anjou brought an army and that you were defeated.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Defeated. Yes. Defeated. Louis died in November. We thought that was the end of it. The Angevins had no army here, no money, no support. Queen Joanna was ready to sign the adoption. The Calabrian barons were with me. I held Reggio, Catanzaro, half the south. Sforza's condottieri were marching north toward Naples itself. Then René came.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Ten thousand men. French knights, Provençal infantry, Genoese crossbowmen. He landed at Gaeta in January with a fleet we never saw coming. Genoa provided the ships. Milan provided the money. They'd rather see a French puppet on the Naples throne than an Aragonese king controlling the western Mediterranean.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Aversa. Two weeks ago. Sforza's men broke. Broke. The finest condottieri in Italy, and they broke against French heavy cavalry. René's knights went through them like paper. I lost two thousand men in an afternoon. The rest scattered. Sforza himself fled to Milan to renegotiate his contract—with René. I hold Naples. This city, this castle, and perhaps a dozen miles in any direction. The barons who swore to me are 'reconsidering their positions.' Queen Joanna has gone silent. And René of Anjou sits at Aversa with an army I cannot match, waiting for me to starve or surrender.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How is he able to sustain such a large campaign and for so long? Does he indeed have such deep pockets?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: René? Deep pockets? The man was ransoming his own jewelry to pay debts three years ago. Duke of Anjou, Duke of Bar, Duke of Lorraine through his wife—titles enough for three kings, and barely the income of a prosperous count. No. René is the sword. Others provide the arm.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The Genoese hate me. Hate Aragon. We threaten their trade routes, their dominance in the western sea. They provided the fleet that brought René's army—forty ships, Juan. Forty. And they didn't do it for love of France. Filippo Maria Visconti. The snake of Milan. He funded Sforza to fight for me, then funded René to fight against me. He plays all sides, always. A strong Aragon in Naples threatens his ambitions in Lombardy. A weak French puppet he can manipulate? That serves him perfectly.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Between them—Genoa's ships, Milan's gold—René has what he needs. For now. But such coalitions are fragile. Visconti will betray René the moment it suits him, just as he betrayed me. The question is whether I survive long enough to see it. There are also whispers about French gold directly. Charles VII is no longer the desperate dauphin hiding behind Joan of Arc's skirts. France recovers. And René is married to Charles's sister-in-law. The French crown may see Naples as worth an investment.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I am not fighting one man, Juan. I am fighting half of Italy and perhaps France itself. And right now, I am losing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What is the naval situation? Can we reinforce Naples from Iberia? Can I land a Castilian army?

roll.outcome: French intervention. René of Anjou arrived with a French army. Alfonso's forces crushed in battle. He's alive but his army is shattered. Years of work undone.

encounters.recap: Alfonso reveals the catastrophic defeat at Aversa two weeks prior, where René of Anjou's French army of 10,000 men crushed his forces and Sforza's condottieri. Backed by Genoa and Milan, René now controls most of southern Italy while Alfonso holds only Naples itself, facing potential siege or surrender.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: There are also whispers about French gold directly. Charles VII is no longer the desperate dauphin hiding behind Joan of Arc's skirts. France recovers. And René is married to Charles's sister-in-law. The French crown may see Naples as worth an investment. I am not fighting one man, Juan. I am fighting half of Italy and perhaps France itself. And right now, I am losing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso moves to the window overlooking the bay, where the masts of ships are visible in the harbor.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: My fleet survives. Mostly. Fourteen war galleys. Eight armed carracks. Some smaller vessels. They're anchored here, under the castello's guns. René has no fleet of his own in these waters—the Genoese returned home after landing his army. They're merchants, not soldiers. They delivered their cargo and left.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The sea is... contested but not closed. Genoese raiders harry the approaches. They took two of my supply ships last month. But they cannot blockade Naples. Not with what they have here. The route from Sicily remains open. My brother controls Palermo. Grain still reaches us.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: From Castile? From Aragon? The voyage is long. A thousand miles from Barcelona. Fifteen hundred from Seville. Through waters where Genoa is strong—the Balearics, Sardinia, the Tyrrhenian. An army would need transport ships, escort vessels, supplies for weeks at sea. Could you land a Castilian army? Yes. In theory. But how large? How soon? René has ten thousand men. To break him in the field, I would need... eight thousand? Ten? Fresh, well-supplied, well-led. And time to coordinate, to plan, to strike before Visconti sends more gold or Genoa sends more ships.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You have ten ships in my harbor, Juan. Knights enough to hold a wall, not storm a field. What exactly are you asking? What are you offering?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso exhales slowly. He moves to a chair and sits heavily, the first time he has allowed himself to show physical exhaustion since Juan entered.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I have three choices. First. I hold Naples and wait. René's coalition is unnatural—Genoa and Milan despise each other. Visconti is already negotiating with Florence against Genoa's interests. Given time, they will turn on each other. They always do. But time requires food, gold, and men. I have perhaps two months of supplies. My treasury is nearly empty. And every week I sit here, more barons abandon me for René.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Second. I negotiate. René is not unreasonable. He might accept my withdrawal in exchange for... something. Recognition of his claim. Perhaps some territorial concession in Sicily or Sardinia. I go home to Aragon with my life and my fleet, and I abandon twelve years of work.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Third. I withdraw to Sicily. Regroup. My brother holds Palermo. The island is loyal. I could rebuild, wait for René's coalition to collapse, return in a year or two or five. My father spent twenty years fighting for this crown. Perhaps I am meant to spend twenty more. What this means for my position? It means I am not yet defeated, but I am not far from it. It means the three-kingdom alliance we dreamed of in Granada is... delayed. Perhaps for years. Perhaps forever. Unless something changes.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Joanna. She is sixty-one years old. She has outlived two husbands, three adopted heirs, and countless predictions of her imminent death. Her health? Failing. She does not leave the Castel Capuano. Her physicians attend her constantly. Some say it is her heart. Others say her lungs. She coughs blood, they whisper. She has been 'dying' for five years. And yet she persists.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: She adopted me in 1421. Revoked it in 1423 for Louis. Was negotiating to restore it when René arrived. Now she waits. She has always waited—playing suitors against each other, never committing until the last possible moment. It is how she has survived. If she dies without naming an heir, Naples descends into chaos—every faction fighting for the crown. If she names René, his position becomes unassailable. If she names me... She will not name me while René sits at Aversa with ten thousand men and I cower behind these walls. Joanna respects strength. She adopted me when I was ascendant. She abandoned me when Louis seemed stronger. Now René holds the field. Why would she choose the losing side?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It's time for Castille to enter this war. If you would accept it. I will sail on to Constantinople and I will write my regent to raise an army to come to Sicily. The Genoese have no reason to fight a christian army on it's way to Sicily. Only when they have arrived do I declare officially. When I have returned from Constantinople, the Castillian army will have arrived. Then we land, strike and end this war. And we cement the three crowns alliance in blood if needed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso goes very still. For a long moment, he simply stares at Juan. The mask of careful diplomacy, the shield of wounded pride—both slip, revealing something raw beneath. Hope. Desperate, dangerous hope. He opens his mouth, closes it. Turns away toward the window. His shoulders rise and fall with a deep breath. When he turns back, his eyes are wet, though no tears fall.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You would do this. Commit Castile to war in Italy. For me. For Naples. The timing... yes. The Genoese cannot justify attacking a Christian fleet bound for Constantinople. By the time your army reaches Sicily, René will have grown complacent. His coalition will have frayed. And then... How many men? An army large enough to break René in the field—eight thousand? Ten? Castile has strength, but your Military Orders have obligations, your nobles have their own concerns. And the cost— Transporting an army across the Mediterranean is ruinously expensive. Feeding them, supplying them, paying them while they wait...

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: What do you want, Juan? We spoke in Granada of alliance. Of three kingdoms united. But this— This is not alliance. This is salvation. You would be rescuing the King of Aragon from his own failed war. That is not a debt easily repaid.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This will however unite our kingdoms and our family. I have spent some time in Barcelona and everyone seems to be talking about the Aragonese succession. That I am the next in line. I have never spoken about this with you personally. How can we prevent another succession war not only for Aragon but for Naples as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso is silent for a long moment. His hand moves absently to the edge of the map, fingers tracing the coastline of Aragon as though touching something precious. When he speaks, his voice is quieter than before. The bluster is gone.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You know, when I was young, I thought I would have sons. Many sons. An heir for Aragon. An heir for Sicily. An heir for Naples, when I won it. A dynasty to rival the Capetians. María and I... we tried. For years. The physicians, the pilgrimages, the prayers. Nothing. And now she is past the age. There will be no sons of my body.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Everyone talks of it. Barcelona, Valencia, Zaragoza, Palermo. They look at me and they see a king without an heir. They look at you and they see... Granada. Constantinople. Two healthy children. A young wife who may give you more. I am not a fool, Juan. I know what the lawyers say. I know the genealogies. If I die without legitimate issue, the Crown of Aragon passes to your line through your mother. And if I win Naples and then die without issue, Naples becomes... complicated.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: So. You offer me an army. You raise the succession. These are not separate things in your mind, I think. What are you proposing, exactly? That we formalize what the lawyers already assume? That we bind Naples to the arrangement somehow? I am not opposed to discussing this. I would rather my life's work pass to you than be torn apart by squabbling cousins and Angevin pretenders.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: But I am also not a man who signs documents while a French army sits ten miles from his walls. Such agreements would look like... coercion. My nobles would question whether I acted freely. Your nobles would wonder what you promised to extract such terms. Win this war with me first. Fight beside me, not merely for me. And when René is broken and Naples is secure—then we discuss how to bind our kingdoms together properly. In strength, not in desperation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extends his hand.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Is that acceptable?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont want Naples to fall into war again. It deserves a clear succession. And it indeed fits into my vision for a christian alliance that can challenge the Ottomans. Let us first win you the crown of Naples cousin. And with me on the field, we shall not fail.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan summons a scribe and dictates a letter to Álvaro. He orders the raising of an army of 15,000 Castilians consisting of noble and crown troops to be ferried to Sicily. The Mendozas are to command the army, which will assemble in Sicily and await Juan's return from Constantinople.

encounters.recap: Juan commits Castile to war in Italy, promising Alfonso a 15,000-man army to be assembled in Sicily while Juan continues to Constantinople. They discuss the Aragonese succession, with Alfonso acknowledging Juan as his likely heir while insisting they win the war before formalizing any agreements. The two kings shake hands on a partnership that will unite their kingdoms and secure Naples against René of Anjou.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso grips Juan's hand firmly. Something passes between them—not quite brotherhood, not yet, but the foundation of it. An understanding.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Cousin

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A scribe is summoned—a nervous Aragonese clerk who was not expecting to take dictation from the King of Castile. He sets up his writing desk with trembling hands, quill poised. Juan dictates a letter to Don Álvaro de Luna, commanding him to raise an army of fifteen thousand men consisting of noble levies and crown troops, to be transported to Sicily under the command of Don Íñigo López de Mendoza. The army is to assemble in Palermo by July 1434 and await Juan's return from Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The scribe looks up, quill hovering.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The date for assembly, Your Majesty? And shall I note anything regarding funding for such an enterprise?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The nobles will be assembling as is their noble obligation. Supplies and transport will be provided by the crown treasury. Assemble the men in Palermo in July 1434.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The scribe nods, writing quickly. The quill scratches across parchment, recording the commands that will set fifteen thousand men in motion across a thousand miles of sea. He finishes with a flourish, sands the ink, and presents the letter for Juan's seal. Alfonso watches in silence as the wax is heated, as Juan's signet ring presses into the crimson blob, as the letter that may decide the fate of three kingdoms is folded and prepared for dispatch.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: July. Four months. That is... ambitious.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to a cabinet, produces a sealed document of his own.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: A letter of passage for your messenger. It will get him through any Aragonese territory without delay. My fastest couriers can have this in Barcelona within a week. From there to Toledo...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He hands the document to the scribe, who bows and hurries from the chamber. When the door closes, Alfonso turns back to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Fifteen thousand men. I asked for eight. Perhaps ten. You offer me an army larger than René's.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pours two cups of wine from a flagon on the side table—simple clay cups, not the silver goblets a king would normally use. A sign of how strained resources have become.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You understand what this means, Juan. If Castile sends fifteen thousand men to fight in Italy, you are not merely aiding an ally. You are declaring to all of Christendom that the Crown of Castile has interests in the Mediterranean. Genoa will see it. Milan will see it. Florence, Venice, the Pope himself. You will have enemies you did not have yesterday.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That was going to happen anyway if our alliance ever came into force. We will guard our islands and the northern Naples forts and we should be quite secure. The pope is our ally so that cuts off most of the approaches. We should maybe ally with Venice if Genoa appears our greatest enemy at sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso drinks, then sets down his cup with a thoughtful expression.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Venice. Yes. The Serenissima hates Genoa—they have been rivals for centuries. And they fear Milan more than anyone. Visconti's ambitions in Lombardy threaten their mainland territories.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back to the map, finger tracing the Adriatic coast.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: But Venice is... careful. They calculate everything. They will not commit to an alliance unless they see clear profit. Their interests lie here. Constantinople. The Black Sea trade. The Aegean islands. They watch the Ottomans with one eye and their account books with the other.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You sail to Constantinople. That may open doors. If you can persuade the Venetians that a strong Christian presence in the eastern Mediterranean serves their commercial interests... They are not sentimental, but they are pragmatic. Gold speaks louder than crusading rhetoric in the Doge's palace.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: As for the Pope—yes, Eugenius supports us. But Rome is not a fortress. The papal states are weak, surrounded by powers that would happily see the Holy Father humbled. Eugenius can write letters and issue bulls. He cannot field armies. Do not rely too heavily on papal favor. It is valuable but fragile. What the Pope gives today, pressure may force him to withdraw tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The northern approaches—Gaeta, Terracina, the coastal fortresses—yes, those must be held. If René is driven south and we control the north, he is trapped between our armies and the sea.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: But all of this assumes you return from Constantinople. The Turks are not French knights, Juan. They are something else entirely. How long do you intend to stay in the East?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will return in July to lead our campaign against the Anjou. We will succeed. And interestingly, our interest in helping the Byzantines creates Venice as a natural ally as our interests align. I will return cousin. Don't worry.

encounters.recap: Juan dictates orders to raise fifteen thousand Castilian troops for Sicily, exceeding Alfonso's expectations. They discuss Mediterranean strategy, potential alliances with Venice against Genoa, and the risks of Juan's upcoming Constantinople mission. The alliance between the cousins is solidified with concrete military commitments.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The Turks fight differently than we do. Faster ships, more archers, different boarding tactics. If your fleet is to operate near Constantinople, your captains must understand what they will face. How long can you remain in Naples? A few days of joint exercises would teach your men more than weeks of drilling alone.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will stay a few days to exercise and re-supply.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Admiral Berenguer is not what Juan expected. A stocky man in his fifties, grey-bearded and weathered, he carries himself with the particular stillness of someone who has survived catastrophe and emerged harder for it.

exchanges.speaker: admiral_berenguer
exchanges.text: Ponza. Your Majesty wants to know about Ponza. Everyone does. The great defeat. We lost because we fought like Christians against Christians. Line abreast, close and board, prize-taking and ransom. The Genoese fought to sink us. We fought to capture them. A man fighting to kill will always defeat a man fighting to profit.

exchanges.speaker: admiral_berenguer
exchanges.text: The Turks are worse. They do not want your ships. They do not want ransom. They want you dead or enslaved. Every man. Every vessel. No quarter, no negotiation, no chivalry. Forget everything you know about naval warfare. I will teach you how to survive.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The exercises begin at dawn. Alfonso has lent four of his war galleys for the drills, their crews demonstrating Ottoman formations while Castilian ships practice responses.

exchanges.speaker: admiral_berenguer
exchanges.text: The Turkish formation—see how they spread wide? They want to envelop. Pin you with the center while the wings curl around. Their archers suppress your deck crews while they close for ramming. There—that's your death. The moment you're surrounded, you're finished. They'll board from three sides at once.

exchanges.speaker: captain_torrelles
exchanges.text: The Turks are not one navy. You have the Sultan's fleet—disciplined, well-supplied, dangerous. You have corsairs—independent raiders, unpredictable but poorly coordinated. And you have local squadrons loyal to various beys and pashas.

exchanges.speaker: captain_torrelles
exchanges.text: Here—the Dardanelles. The Turks control both shores. Any fleet approaching Constantinople must pass through waters they dominate. Night passage, or overwhelming force. There is no other way. But the Turks have weaknesses. Their galleys are fast but fragile. Your carracks can take punishment they cannot. Your cannons outrange their bows. If you hold formation—if you do not let them swarm you—you can hurt them badly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The final day brings everything together. Castilian and Aragonese ships operate as a combined fleet, running through scenarios Berenguer has designed: ambush responses, convoy defense, fighting withdrawal.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I have sailed for thirty years. I thought I knew the sea. Berenguer has shown me I was a child playing at war. What we learned these four days... We are not ready to challenge the Sultan's fleet. But we are ready to survive it. To protect our convoy, to reach Constantinople, to fight our way out if we must. The men feel it too. Castilian and Aragonese, drilling together—it means something. They see we are not alone in these waters.

roll.outcome: Excellent training. A breakthrough in coordination and understanding. Admiral Berenguer's hard-won lessons from Ponza transform how Castilian captains think about naval combat. Real readiness for Ottoman encounters.

encounters.recap: Over four days, Juan's fleet conducts intensive naval exercises with Alfonso's experienced captains in Naples harbor. Admiral Berenguer, survivor of the defeat at Ponza, teaches anti-galley tactics and Ottoman naval doctrine. The training proves highly successful, with Castilian and Aragonese crews developing strong cooperation and the fleet gaining genuine readiness for eastern Mediterranean waters and potential Ottoman encounters.

encounters.location: Ionian Sea to Crete, Harbor of Candia

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first week passes smoothly. The fleet rounds Sicily through the Strait of Messina without incident, the volcanic peak of Etna smoking lazily on the horizon as they slip through the narrow waters. The crews, still sharp from the Naples exercises, maintain formation with a discipline that makes Captain Vargas nod approvingly. Lucia spends the days on deck when weather permits, watching the coastlines slide past—first Italy, then the scattered Greek islands. Catalina has become a favorite of the sailors, toddling across the deck with her wooden horse while weathered men soften into smiles. On the eighth day, the sky begins to change.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. There's weather coming. Bad weather. That's a Gregale building. Northeast wind—it comes down from the Balkans this time of year. When it hits... We have choices, Your Majesty. We run south, try to find shelter in Crete—but that's half a day's sailing and we may not make it before the storm hits. We heave to and ride it out here in open water—the ships can take it, but we'll be scattered to hell and back. Or we press northeast, try to outrun it to Rhodes. The carracks are sturdy but slow. The galleys are fast but fragile in heavy seas. Whatever we do, we do it together or we lose ships trying.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We sail for Crete and wait it out there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet flies before the building wind, sails straining, bows cutting through swells that grow taller with each passing hour. The Cretan coastline emerges from the haze—brown hills, white villages, the promise of shelter. Juan finds Catalina in the great cabin with Lucia and the ladies-in-waiting. The child looks up as her father enters, immediately reaching for him. Juan carries her up to the quarterdeck. The wind whips at their clothes, carrying the salt-spray smell of the angry sea. To the northeast, the sky has become a wall of bruised darkness, shot through with flickers of distant lightning. The sea beneath it is the color of iron.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá! Barcos moving fast! Grande. Dios.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: The Lord's wrath. Or His mercy, depending on whether we make harbor. Candia, Your Majesty. We'll make it. Perhaps half an hour to spare.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet slides into the great Venetian harbor as the first true gusts of the Gregale begin to shriek. The sea walls of Candia rise around them—massive fortifications built to hold against Ottoman sieges, now sheltering ten Castilian ships from nature's assault. From the safety of the harbor, Juan watches the Gregale turn the open sea into a churning nightmare of white water and driving rain. Within the hour, a Venetian harbor boat approaches the Santa Catalina despite the weather—oarsmen fighting the chop, a canopy barely protecting the passengers from the driving rain.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. I am Marco Contarini, deputy to the Governor of Candia. The Serenissima welcomes your fleet to shelter. And... fortune has provided an unusual coincidence. This gentleman arrived three days ago, bound eventually for Rome. When he heard a Castilian fleet had entered the harbor—a fleet flying crusader crosses—he begged to speak with you immediately.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I am Georgios Sphrantzes, protovestiarios to His Imperial Majesty John VIII Palaiologos. I carry letters for the Pope and the Christian kings. But God has placed you in my path first. The Emperor has spoken of you—the king who completed the Reconquista. The king who promised aid. Your Majesty, Constantinople's situation has changed. I must tell you what has happened before you sail into those waters.

roll.outcome: Unexpected advantage. The run to Crete brings the fleet into contact with someone useful—a Venetian official, a merchant with news, or another Christian vessel with valuable information.

encounters.recap: A fierce Gregale storm forces Juan's fleet to take shelter in Crete's harbor of Candia. The fleet makes it to safety with time to spare, but the storm brings an unexpected encounter with Georgios Sphrantzes, Byzantine protovestiarios carrying urgent news about Constantinople's situation.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I carry letters for the Pope and the Christian kings, continuing our appeal for aid. But God has placed you in my path first—the king who completed the Reconquista, the king whose knights already stand on our walls. Your three hundred men under Don Juan de Sotomayor have been a blessing, Your Majesty. The Emperor speaks of you often. If Your Majesty permits, I could brief you on the current state of the city, the Ottoman dispositions, the political situation you will encounter. So that when you arrive, you arrive prepared.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Welcome aboard. This is my wife Lucia and this is Catalina. Princess Catalina. Tell us what is going on.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes bows to Lucia with practiced courtly grace, and his stern face softens noticeably when he sees Catalina peering at him from behind her wooden horse. The Venetian official, Contarini, clears his throat and suggests they continue the conversation in the harbor master's quarters out of the rain.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The storm howls outside, but the stone building is warm and dry. Wine and food have been provided—Venetian hospitality for a king, even an unexpected one. Catalina has been taken to rest with Lucia and the ladies in an adjoining chamber. Sphrantzes sits across from Juan, his Byzantine robes now dried, his composure restored. The Venetian official has withdrawn to give them privacy.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The situation in Constantinople, Your Majesty. I will speak plainly, as one Christian to another. The city endures. Your three hundred knights under Don Juan de Sotomayor patrol the walls and train our militia. Their presence has been... a balm to the people's spirits. For the first time in years, we see Western soldiers who have come to help, not to plunder. But the city itself is a shadow. Forty thousand souls, perhaps fewer, in walls built for half a million. Entire quarters stand empty. Farmers plant wheat inside the city walls because there are not enough people to fill the houses. The Theodosian Walls— Your sixty thousand florins helped. But the walls stretch four miles, Your Majesty. Towers crumble. Gates rot. We patch what we can.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Sultan Murad is not currently at war with us. We pay him tribute—three hundred thousand silver coins each year—and he permits us to exist. His attention is elsewhere. The Karamanids in Anatolia. Troubles in the Balkans. He could take Constantinople if he wished, but why spend ten thousand lives storming walls when the fruit will fall into his hand eventually? He waits. We wither. This is what you sail into, Your Majesty. Not a siege. Not a battle. A slow death. The Emperor prays your arrival will change the calculation—show Murad that the West has not abandoned us, that attacking Constantinople means war with more than just our exhausted garrison.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How much is this tribute of 300,000 in florins?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The tribute is paid in aspra—Byzantine silver. At current exchange rates, perhaps thirty thousand florins. Perhaps thirty-five. It fluctuates with the silver markets. Thirty thousand florins, Your Majesty. Each year. Paid to a Sultan who could take the city whenever he wishes, simply for the privilege of continuing to exist. That sum would rebuild a section of the walls. It would hire a thousand mercenaries for a year. It would feed the city's poor for a decade. Instead, it fills Murad's treasury. And yet we pay. Because the alternative is war, and we cannot survive a determined siege. Not as we are now. The tribute buys us time—time we spend praying that the West will remember Constantinople exists. Your sixty thousand florins, Your Majesty—the aid you sent last year—that was nearly two years of tribute. The Emperor wept when he received it. Not from joy alone, but from shame. That a foreign king would give so freely what we beggar ourselves to pay our enemies.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And now I sail to his city to see how we can help long-term. I am looking forward to it.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I have traveled to Rome, to Venice, to Buda, to a dozen courts. I have begged and pleaded and debased myself before princes who nodded politely and gave nothing. Who spoke of 'the Turkish question' as though it were an abstract problem of philosophy rather than— Forgive me. I am... not accustomed to kings who say they will come and then actually come. The Emperor will receive you with every honor Constantinople can still muster. It is not what it was—we cannot offer the pageantry of our grandfathers' time—but what we have, we will give. You mentioned long-term aid. The Emperor will wish to discuss this at length, of course. But if I may be so bold—there are three things Constantinople needs above all else. Walls. Men. And a reason for Murad to fear the cost of attack. Your presence alone may provide the third. The other two...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will have to see for myself what the situation is before I can develop a plan. I have offered Constantinople three choices. Leave and find refuge in my kingdom, stay on your own terms and probably perish with your pride and head held high. Or fight if we can actually win and fight with everything we have. Has the emperor considered these options? And how is the mood about these choices in the city?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's letter was... much discussed. The Emperor read it aloud to his closest advisors. I was present. The first option—refuge in Castile. The Emperor is grateful for the offer. Profoundly grateful. But you must understand what you are asking. The Palaiologoi have held Constantinople for nearly two hundred years. Before them, other dynasties stretching back to Constantine himself. Eleven centuries, Your Majesty. To abandon the city... It would be more than exile. It would be the death of an idea. The Emperor would become a pensioner in a foreign court, a curiosity, a relic. His children would grow up Castilian, not Roman. Within two generations, the name Palaiologos would mean nothing. Some in the city whisper that this would be wisdom. That survival matters more than pride. But they whisper it quietly, and never to the Emperor's face.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The second option—to stay and perish with dignity. There are those who would choose this. The monks especially. They say it is better to die Roman and Orthodox than to live as slaves or beggars. The Emperor... He has not ruled this out. If the end must come, he will die on the walls. This I know. But the third option, Your Majesty. To fight, truly fight, with a real chance of victory. This is what the Emperor prays for. This is why he sends men like me to grovel before Western princes. Not for charity. For alliance. But what does 'fight with everything we have' mean? Constantinople alone cannot defeat the Ottomans. We know this. The question is whether the West will commit—truly commit—to a war that may last years, cost tens of thousands of lives, and offer no guarantee of success.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The mood in the city, Your Majesty? It is the mood of people who have been disappointed too many times to hope openly. They have heard promises before. They have seen Western knights arrive with grand speeches and leave with Byzantine gold. When your three hundred men came and stayed—when they patrolled the walls and trained beside our soldiers instead of demanding payments and privileges—it was like water in a desert. The people are watching, Your Majesty. Waiting to see if you are different. The Emperor is watching too.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think the third option will only be a possibility if Constantinople joins with Naples, Aragon, Castille and Portugal in one grand Empire or alliance. Only then will we be able to turn back the turks. Otherwise Iberians will just be dying for someone else's glory. What this will look like, I am not sure about yet. And I will discuss this with the emperor at length. But something like this is the only way towards victory that is lasting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes goes very still. The fire crackles. Rain lashes the windows. For a long moment, the Byzantine diplomat simply looks at Juan, his dark eyes unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: A grand alliance. Or empire. Your Majesty speaks plainly. I will do the same. What you propose is... not without precedent. Centuries ago, Crusader princes carved kingdoms from the East. They called themselves defenders of Christendom. Within a generation, they were warring with each other and treating with Muslims against fellow Christians. Within two centuries, they were gone. I do not say this to offend. I say it because the Emperor will think it, even if he does not speak it. Byzantium has seen Western 'alliances' before. The Fourth Crusade came to save us from the infidel—and sacked Constantinople instead. Stole our relics. Burned our libraries. Put a Latin emperor on our throne for sixty years. The people remember, Your Majesty. The priests remember. When they hear 'grand alliance with the West,' they think of 1204. And yet.

encounters.recap: George Sphrantzes briefs Juan on Constantinople's dire situation: a city of 40,000 in walls built for half a million, paying 30,000 florins annual tribute to Sultan Murad, slowly withering. Juan proposes his three options for the Emperor and suggests a grand alliance of Western kingdoms as the only path to lasting victory. Sphrantzes responds with diplomatic caution, citing Byzantine memories of betrayal by Western crusaders, particularly the sack of 1204.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: What you propose is... not without precedent. Centuries ago, Crusader princes carved kingdoms from the East. They called themselves defenders of Christendom. Within a generation, they were warring with each other and treating with Muslims against fellow Christians. Within two centuries, they were gone.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I do not say this to offend. I say it because the Emperor will think it, even if he does not speak it. Byzantium has seen Western 'alliances' before. The Fourth Crusade came to save us from the infidel—and sacked Constantinople instead. Stole our relics. Burned our libraries. Put a Latin emperor on our throne for sixty years.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The people remember, Your Majesty. The priests remember. When they hear 'grand alliance with the West,' they think of 1204.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: And yet we are dying. Slowly, certainly, but dying nonetheless. The Emperor knows this. He is not a fool, nor is he ruled by pride alone. If there is a path to genuine survival—not charity, not temporary rescue, but lasting security... He will listen. But Your Majesty must understand what you are asking. You speak of Constantinople joining an Iberian alliance. To Byzantine ears, this sounds like... submission. Like becoming a province of a Western empire rather than the heart of our own.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: What would this union look like? Would the Emperor bend the knee to Castile? Would Constantinople become a vassal? Would the Orthodox Church submit to Rome? These questions will be asked, Your Majesty. By the Emperor, by his court, by the Patriarch, by the people in the streets. If you wish to propose such an alliance, you must have answers.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I understand. I will speak them with the emperor. And hear what he has to say. And he will listen to what I have to say. Then we will see what they choose. Was there anything else you wanted to speak to me about?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Two matters, Your Majesty. One practical, one... delicate. The practical matter first. When you arrive, there will be ceremony. The Emperor will insist upon it—not from vanity, but because Constantinople must show the world it still commands respect. Your entrance will be watched. How the Emperor receives you, where you are housed, what honors are offered—all of this sends messages. To our people. To the Ottoman spies who infest the city. To Venice and Genoa and everyone else with interests in the East.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I tell you this so you are not surprised. The pageantry may seem excessive for a city so diminished. But it is... necessary. It is how we remind ourselves, and others, that we are still Rome. The delicate matter. The Church. Your Majesty comes bearing papal favor. You have reformed the Western Church, allied with Eugenius, earned the Pope's blessing. This is known. And it creates... complications.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The Emperor seeks union with Rome. He believes it is the only way to secure Western aid on the scale we need. But the Patriarch, the monks, many of the clergy and common people—they would rather die Orthodox than submit to the Pope. The wound of 1204 runs deep, but the wound of theology runs deeper.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: If you arrive as a champion of Rome demanding religious submission as the price of alliance, you will find doors closing before you. But if you arrive as a Christian king seeking to defend a Christian city—leaving the question of Church union to churchmen—you may find more friends than you expect. I offer this only as counsel, Your Majesty. The Emperor will make his own choices. But the religious question has destroyed better alliances than ours.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The church is reforming even as we speak. You have heard of the hussites and how even they have found their place in the structure of the church. The matter of the filiosque does not need to be resolved, the church is large and even within it's ranks there is space for somewhat different interpretations. In fact; what are we even talking about? We are all christians are we not? Would the Greeks consider coming back to the church with their dogma intact?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... better informed on theology than most Western kings I have met. The Filioque. Yes. That is the word that has divided Christendom for four hundred years. Such a small thing—and the Son—three words in a creed. And yet men have died over it. Churches have split. Empires have turned their backs on each other while the infidel advances.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: You ask if the Greeks would return to communion with Rome with their dogma intact. This is... This is the question, Your Majesty. The only question that matters. The Emperor would accept it in a heartbeat. He cares about survival, not theology. He would kiss the Pope's ring tomorrow if it brought fifty thousand soldiers to Constantinople's defense.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: But the Emperor is not the Church. The Patriarch—the monks of Mount Athos—the parish priests—the babushkas who light candles in every church in the city— They remember what their grandfathers taught them. That Rome demands submission. That the Latins want to change us, not embrace us. That union means becoming something we are not.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The Hussites, you say, have found their place. I confess I do not know the details of this arrangement. But I know what the Orthodox would need to hear. First—that the Filioque is not imposed. That we may continue to recite the Creed as we always have. Second—that our rites are respected. Our liturgy, our calendar, our traditions of married clergy, our way of making the sign of the cross. Third—that the Patriarch of Constantinople is not made subordinate to Rome, but recognized as equal in honor, if not in primacy. Fourth—and this is the hardest—that Rome admits the Fourth Crusade was a crime. That the sack of Constantinople was sin. That the Latin Empire was illegitimate.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Can Rome offer this? Would the Pope accept Greeks as brothers rather than wayward children returning to obedience? Would the cardinals permit an Eastern church that does not conform to Western practice? If so, Your Majesty—if you could deliver such terms—you would accomplish what councils and emperors have failed to achieve for centuries. The Church would reunite. East and West would stand together against the Turk. But I have been a diplomat for thirty years. I have learned that what kings promise and what popes deliver are not always the same thing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Too bad. If these would be the terms of the Greeks, then I dont see any possibility of the church joining. The Vatican rules supreme and the Greeks will have to ecknowledge that they are part of a greater church where they are a minority. Their number warrant a cardinal in Rome, but not one of equal station. Surely they understand this no? And if they don't I will respect their choice.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks more plainly than any Western prince I have ever met. You are correct, of course. The Greeks are few. Rome is vast. The mathematics of the matter are what they are. And yet mathematics have never moved the hearts of men who believe their souls are at stake.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I will tell you something I would not tell most Western kings. The Emperor agrees with you. He knows we cannot negotiate as equals—we have nothing to bargain with but our history and our pride. He would accept papal supremacy tomorrow if it meant survival. He has said as much to me in private.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: But the Emperor is not a tyrant. He cannot force the Church to submit. If the Patriarch refuses—if the monks refuse—if the people refuse—then union becomes a document signed by emperors and ignored by everyone else. And the resentment it breeds may be worse than no union at all. This is the trap we are in, Your Majesty. The Emperor wants to live. The Church wants to die Orthodox. And I... I am simply a messenger, carrying impossible choices between men who cannot agree.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I will convey your words to the Emperor faithfully. He will appreciate your honesty, even if the terms are... difficult. Better to know where a man stands than to chase shadows. May I ask one thing, Your Majesty? If the Church cannot unite—if the Orthodox cannot bring themselves to submit to Rome—does that end the possibility of alliance? Or is there a path to cooperation that does not require the Greeks to renounce what they believe?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Better to let me speak with the emperor directly. I am on my way there now. I will lay out the choices before him and let him choose. Mending the scism would have been a nice bonus, but not a requirement for an alliance no.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Not a requirement. Your Majesty, you have no idea how rare those words are.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes rises and bows—a deep bow, more genuine than the formal courtesies he offered earlier.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I have taken enough of your time, and you have a family to attend to in this storm. But I thank you for this conversation. It has been... Clarifying. The storm should blow itself out by tomorrow evening, perhaps the morning after. If Your Majesty permits, I will abandon my journey to Rome and sail with your fleet to Constantinople. The Emperor will want to know what manner of man approaches his city, and I would rather he hear it from me than from rumors and speculation.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Besides, I find I am curious to see what happens when you and His Imperial Majesty sit down together. It may be the most honest conversation Constantinople has had with the West in centuries.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course, join us! We sail at best speed to Constantinople.

encounters.recap: Sphrantzes probes the practical and theological implications of a Castilian-Byzantine alliance. Juan's blunt honesty about papal supremacy closes the door on church reunion but opens possibilities for purely political cooperation. Sphrantzes agrees to join the fleet to Constantinople, impressed by Juan's unprecedented candor with the East.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The storm blows itself out by the evening of April 6th. The fleet departs Candia on the morning of April 7th, sails filled with clean post-storm winds. The Aegean is kind to them. Island after island slides past—Karpathos, Rhodes glimpsed in the distance, the scattered Cyclades. Sphrantzes proves invaluable, pointing out landmarks, explaining which islands are Venetian, which Genoese, which Ottoman, which belong to the Knights Hospitaller.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Dardanelles approach on April 11th. The crews grow tense—Ottoman fortresses visible on both shores, smoke rising from watchfires. Turkish galleys are spotted, distant shapes observing from the Asian side. But they do not approach.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: They see crusader crosses. They see ten ships, not two or three. They will report to their commanders, but they will not risk a battle without orders. Murad does not want war with the West. Not yet.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The passage takes most of a day, the fleet moving in tight formation, cannons ready but not run out. By evening, they emerge into the Sea of Marmara. April 14, 1434 — Constantinople. The city appears at dawn. Even diminished, even crumbling, Constantinople takes the breath away. The massive Theodosian Walls stretch across the horizon, tower after tower after tower. The dome of the Hagia Sophia rises above the urban sprawl, catching the morning light. The Golden Horn glitters beyond.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina is on deck, held in Juan's arms, pointing excitedly at everything.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Ciudad grande, Papá!

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, little one. The greatest city in the world. Once.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: She is still beautiful. Even now. Even dying.

roll.outcome: Smooth sailing. Favorable winds, no incidents. The Dardanelles passage goes easier than expected. Fleet arrives in good order.

encounters.recap: The Castilian fleet departs Crete after the storm and enjoys favorable winds across the Aegean. Ottoman galleys observe but do not intercept at the Dardanelles. The fleet arrives safely at Constantinople on April 14th, 1434, with the great city's walls and Hagia Sophia dome rising majestically from the harbor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet approaches the Golden Horn, signal flags raised in the universal patterns of peaceful approach. The harbor should be opening before them—Byzantine pilots coming out to guide them to anchorage, officials preparing to receive a Christian king. Instead, the harbor chain remains raised.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: This is... unexpected. The Emperor knew I was traveling west. He would have received word of your fleet. This should not—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A small boat finally emerges from behind the chain. A haggard-looking official climbs the rope ladder, his robes disheveled, his face pale with evident anxiety. He sees Sphrantzes and nearly collapses with relief.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The official speaks rapidly in panicked Greek to Sphrantzes, who responds sharply before turning to Juan with a grave expression.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. There has been... an incident. Three days ago. A Genoese merchant was murdered in the city—stabbed in the Venetian quarter. The Genoese colony claims it was a Venetian plot. The Venetians claim it was Genoese provocation. Both communities have armed their men. There has been fighting in the streets. The Emperor has closed the harbor to prevent either side from bringing in reinforcements. He fears open warfare between the Italian quarters. And now a fleet flying crusader crosses arrives—and no one knows whose side you are on.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dear harbour master, I am king Juan of Castille. Hopefully, you know that I have not taken sides in the Genoese - Venetian conflict. I am merely sailing here as promised to deliver on my promise to the Byzantine people. I have come to help. The Protovestiarios can corroborate my story.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The harbor official stares at Juan, then at Sphrantzes, then back at Juan. Something shifts in his face—the rigid mask of bureaucratic caution cracking, replaced by something more desperate. More human.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: King Juan of Castile, he repeats. The king whose knights stand on our walls. The king who sent sixty thousand florins when no one else would send a copper. He turns to Sphrantzes and speaks rapidly in Greek. Sphrantzes responds, his tone sharp, commanding.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: He says the city has been holding its breath for three days. The Emperor has confined himself to the palace, trying to mediate between the Venetians and Genoese. Both sides have barricaded their quarters. There have been killings—four dead, perhaps more. The city guard is stretched thin. Our own garrison does not dare intervene for fear of being seen as taking sides. He says that perhaps God has sent you at exactly the right moment. A Christian king with no loyalty to Venice or Genoa. Knights who answer to neither Italian power. Someone who can stand between them without being accused of partisanship.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The official barks orders to his oarsmen. The small boat pushes off, racing back toward the chain. Within minutes, the great iron links begin to descend into the water with a groaning rattle that echoes across the harbor. Signal fires light on the walls—not warnings, but announcements.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Word will reach the palace before we dock. The Emperor will know you have arrived—and he will know why the harbor opened for you when it opened for no one else. This is either a gift or a burden, Your Majesty. The city will look to you to help solve a problem that is not yours.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I go and get Lucia and Catalina. Lucia, we are about to meet the last Roman Emperor. Wear your finest and keep Catalina company.

roll.outcome: Eager assistance. The official practically begs Juan to help restore order. Chain lowered immediately. Imperial officials summoned. The arrival becomes an opportunity to calm the city.

encounters.recap: Juan's fleet arrives at Constantinople to find the harbor chain raised due to violent conflict between Venetian and Genoese communities. After Juan identifies himself and his peaceful intentions, the harbor official eagerly welcomes him as a potential neutral mediator. The chain is lowered and word sent to the Emperor, positioning Juan as someone who might help resolve the crisis.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Word will reach the palace before we dock. The Emperor will know you have arrived—and he will know why the harbor opened for you when it opened for no one else. This is either a gift or a burden, Your Majesty. The city will look to you to help solve a problem that is not yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet begins to move forward into the Golden Horn. On the docks ahead, people are gathering—soldiers, merchants, common folk emerging from their homes to see the ships flying crusader crosses. And beyond the docks, visible above the rooftops, the dome of the Hagia Sophia gleams in the morning light.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I go and get Lucia and Catalina. Lucia, we are about to meet the last Roman Emperor. Wear your finest and keep Catalina company. Catalina, we are about to meet some important and serious people. Catalina must be brave and quiet and stay with mama ok? Can you do that?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The last Roman Emperor. I had hoped for a bath first, but I suppose history does not wait for such things.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Importante. Seria. Catalina brave. Y quiet.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She will be good for perhaps ten minutes, my love. After that, God alone knows what she will do.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan stands at the rail in his finest—not armor, but the rich garments of a Christian king: deep Castilian crimson, the golden castle-and-lion of his arms embroidered on his chest, his father's sword at his hip. Lucia is beside him in emerald silk, her dark hair bound up in the Italian fashion, composed and regal despite the chaos they are sailing into. Catalina rests on her mother's hip, wooden horse clutched tight, her small face a mask of determined seriousness. Behind them, the knights have assembled on deck in ranks—not armed for battle, but in clean surcoats, polished mail visible beneath. A statement: we come in peace, but we are not weak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The docks are crowded, but the crowd is strange—clusters of people who do not mix. Byzantine soldiers in worn uniforms form a loose cordon. Behind them, civilians watch: Greeks in threadbare robes, a knot of merchants who might be Venetian from their dress, another group standing pointedly apart who are likely Genoese. The tension is palpable—a city holding its breath.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Emperor John VIII Palaiologos is perhaps forty years old, thin and careworn, with a closely-trimmed beard going grey at the edges. His robes are magnificent—the ancient purple of Rome—but they hang on him like garments made for a larger man. His crown is gold, set with pearls and rubies, but it seems to weigh heavily on his brow. His eyes, though. His eyes are sharp, alive, desperate.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_john_viii
exchanges.text: King Juan of Castile. You promised aid, and you have come. You sent gold when others sent words. You sent knights when others sent prayers. Welcome to Constantinople, brother king. We have much to discuss.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Emperor, thank you for receiving us. Let us get comfortable and then talk. We have been many weeks at sea and my family is glad to have solid ground under their feet again. And can we then talk about crowns and empires.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_john_viii
exchanges.text: Of course. You must rest. Your wife and daughter must be weary. The Palace of Blachernae will receive you. It is... not what it was in my grandfather's day, but it remains suitable for a king.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_john_viii
exchanges.text: Crowns and empires. Yes. We will speak of such things. But perhaps first, you might advise me on a more immediate matter. A murdered merchant.
