Two Italian quarters armed for war in my city. And an Emperor who cannot be seen to favor either side without losing the trade that keeps his people fed. You are, I am told, a king who solves problems. Here is one. What would you do?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Have you summoned both sides to you for an audience?

exchanges.speaker: emperor_john_viii
exchanges.text: Summoned. Yes. The Venetian bailo sent his regrets. Urgent matters of commerce requiring his attention. The Genoese podestà was more direct—he does not negotiate while Venetian assassins walk free. I could compel them, of course. I am Emperor. I could send my guard to drag them before me in chains. But an Emperor who must drag merchants to audience has already lost the audience. You have dealt with proud men who believe themselves beyond summoning, I think. Granada did not fall to a king who waited for his enemies to come to him.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I know what I would do if I were in your shoes. But it would be wrong of me to solve this problem on my own. It is a matter of authority and if I would use mine, it would reduce yours. How is your legal system. Is it as free of corruption as could reasonably be expected? Would this ideally be resolved in such a court?

exchanges.speaker: emperor_john_viii
exchanges.text: You understand authority. That is... not always the case with Western kings. Our courts. The law of Rome has endured for a thousand years. Our judges are learned. Our procedures are ancient and thorough. But the Italian quarters do not answer to Roman law. They have their own courts, their own judges, their own rights—granted by my predecessors in exchange for trade and coin. A Venetian murders a Genoese, or a Genoese murders a Venetian, and each side claims jurisdiction. Each side claims the other's court is corrupt, biased, illegitimate. If I intervene and declare one court competent, I have taken a side. If I establish an imperial tribunal, both will refuse to recognize it. If I do nothing... You see the result. You speak of reducing my authority. It is a kind thought. But what authority remains to reduce when merchants ignore imperial summons and arm their quarters like petty lords?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So the traders both hold sovereign authority. Venetians and Genoese are at each other's throats. What else is new? How is this your problem then?

exchanges.speaker: emperor_john_viii
exchanges.text: It is my problem, King Juan, because when Venetians and Genoese kill each other in the streets, it is Byzantine blood that spills between them. My subjects. Caught in crossfire. Beaten for being in the wrong quarter at the wrong hour. It is my problem because if the fighting spreads—if one side burns the other's warehouses—the grain ships stop coming. And then my people starve. Not Venetians. Not Genoese. My people. It is my problem because every day this continues, every day the Emperor of Rome cannot keep order in his own capital, the Sultan's spies write reports. And Murad learns that Constantinople is weaker than he thought. That perhaps the tribute he collects is less than he could take by force. You ask what else is new. Nothing. This is old. This is what my empire has become—a carcass that dogs fight over while the wolf watches from the hills. So. Is it still not your problem either?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And has this happened yet? Have your people been caught in the crossfire? Or will this inevitably happen if the situation continues? Are you and your people affected by this conflict already?

encounters.recap: Juan arrives at Constantinople's docks with his family and is formally welcomed by Emperor John VIII Palaiologos. The Emperor immediately presents Juan with a crisis: Venetian and Genoese merchants are armed and feuding over a murder, threatening the city's stability and grain supply. Juan probes the Emperor's authority and the nature of the problem while the Emperor tests Juan's commitment to solving Constantinople's challenges.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: So. Is it still not your problem either?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Four dead. That we know of. Over three days. Two Genoese. One Venetian. And one— One was a Greek boy. Fifteen years old. A baker's apprentice. He was carrying bread through the Genoese quarter when the fighting started. Wrong place. Wrong hour.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: His father came to the palace. Knelt before me. Asked for justice. I had none to give him. The Genoese say it was an accident. The Venetians say it proves Genoese brutality. And the boy is still dead.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: So yes. It has happened. Not a massacre. Not yet. But the quarters are barricaded. My people who live near the boundaries have fled to churches, to relatives, to anywhere they think is safe. Trade has stopped. The markets are half-empty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We demand to speak with the highest authorities of both traders. They are summoned to your palace where you will demand relations to return to normal relations between Genoa and Venice. They can live within your walls if they can keep the peace, if they can't then they will be thrown out. We give them a week or so to let them settle accounts between them. Let them come to an understanding on their own that settles the matter. After that, the barricades come down, the swords are put away and my men can provide security in the beginning. If the peace is violated by any individual, you throw them out of the city.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: They have already refused my summons. What changes when I summon them again? They will send the same regrets. The same excuses. And the Emperor will have been ignored twice instead of once.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You say your men can provide security. Castilian knights patrolling Byzantine streets, keeping Italian merchants in line. And when the Venetian bailo writes to the Doge that the Emperor of Rome cannot keep order without Spanish soldiers? When the Genoese podestà tells his masters that Constantinople is now a Castilian protectorate?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have already graciously asked for them to come. Now you demand they come. As long as they understand that this is not a request and that you will drag them out with force if needed, they will come. In regards to my knights providing security, I can offer it to them directly. If they both feel comfortable with me providing security, then it is not you who is imposing my knights on them. And what does it cost you? This situation has already cost you. And doing nothing will continue to cost you. You are simply afraid. Just do what needs to be done and step over the fear.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor's face goes very still. For a long moment, he simply looks at Juan. The fountain trickles beside them. Somewhere in the distance, a dog barks. The servants and guards wait at the edge of the courtyard, too far to hear but close enough to watch.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You are bold, King of Castile. I have ruled this empire for nine years. Before that, I was regent for my father. I have negotiated with sultans. I have begged Western princes for aid. I have watched my brothers plot against me and my treasury drain to nothing. And now a young king—victorious, wealthy, secure on his throne—tells me I am simply afraid. Perhaps you are right. Perhaps I have grown too cautious. Too accustomed to managing decline instead of fighting it.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I will consider your proposal. The summons. The ultimatum. Your knights. We will speak more after you have rested. You and your family will be shown to your quarters. Tonight there will be a dinner. Small. Private. We can continue this discussion then.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Where can my men assemble? Is there a field within the walls that I can use?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Five hundred knights and their horses. The Hippodrome is rubble and weeds now, but the ground is flat. It will serve for assembly and drill. Your men already serving on the walls—Don Juan de Sotomayor's company—they are quartered near the Gate of Charisius. Sphrantzes will arrange for your forces to join them, or to remain separate, as you prefer. The Hippodrome is... it was once the heart of the city. Chariot races. Imperial ceremonies. A hundred thousand Romans cheering. Now it is empty. But perhaps it is fitting that Castilian crusaders should gather where emperors once celebrated victories.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: That was... boldly done, Your Majesty. The Emperor does not hear such words often. Perhaps not ever.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I arrange for all my crusaders to assemble in the hippodrome. We will present ourselves there. All the knights in the city will gather there. Dear Sphrantzes, would you like the honour of attending us when we present ourselves? We have sworn to come here some time ago, bear witness to us as we fulfill our oath.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The honor, Your Majesty, would be mine. I have witnessed many things in my years of service. Emperors crowned. Treaties signed. Promises made and broken. I have never witnessed an oath fulfilled. Not from the West. Not like this. I will send word to Don Juan de Sotomayor immediately. His three hundred will be eager to see their king—and to stand beside their brothers. The thirty-four who arrived last month from Barcelona are quartered with them. Nine hundred and fifteen knights, Your Majesty. Assembled under the white banner in the Hippodrome of Constantinople. The city will see. The Emperor will see. And the Ottoman spies will write very interesting reports tonight.

encounters.recap: Juan confronts Emperor John VIII about his inaction regarding Genoese-Venetian violence that has killed four people including a Greek baker's boy. Despite the Emperor's initial defensiveness about his authority being undermined, Juan's blunt counsel that he is 'simply afraid' leads to grudging acknowledgment. The Emperor agrees to consider Juan's proposal for forced negotiations while granting use of the Hippodrome for assembling all 915 Castilian knights under the white banner, with Sphrantzes honored to witness this fulfillment of crusading oaths.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome is a ghost of what it was. The great arena that once held a hundred thousand screaming Romans is now an expanse of packed earth and wild grass. The tiered seating has crumbled into rubble, colonized by weeds and the occasional scraggly tree. But the space remains. Vast. Open. Haunted by echoes of glory. And filling it now: knights. Nine hundred and fifteen knights under the white banner with its red cross, snapping in the afternoon breeze.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan raises his hand. The trumpeters lift their instruments—long brass clarions that catch the afternoon light. The drummers ready their nakers, the paired kettledrums hanging at their waists. Then the sound. The trumpets cry out first—a clear, piercing note that echoes off the ancient walls of the Hippodrome, rolls across the ruins, carries out over the city. The drums join in—a deep, steady rhythm like a heartbeat.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers! One year ago, I made a promise to help Constantinople in it's hour of need. Words sometimes ring hollow when they are not followed up by action. But not today! We stand here in this ancient place to hold our oaths fulfilled. We have promised to come and we came. We are strong and determined but the task before us is monumentous. We face the Ottomans, an enemy that not only outnumbers us, but is also more advanced in terms of organization, science and land. Long has been our journey and we have already seen many of the Lord's wonders. We have been tested and some of our number have already fallen. But we have preservered. We have carried on. We took up the challenge and we have adapted. We have trained and drilled. We are now more ready then we were when we departed. We will continue to adapt, improve and train. And if we adapt and train enough, and when enough sweat and blood has been spilled we may yet be deserving of victory. Victory seems so long away. We stand in the ruins of the hippodrome. A location that was once great. We are in a city that has been hollowed out, a city that was once the jewel of the world. We do not shy away from what is in front of us for it is the plain truth for it does not help us. Instead, we are here to show the Byzantines and the world that the light has not gone out in the east. That christians remember their brotherhood, even after being apart for centuries. We are here to say: Not yet and not today! Not as long as we draw breath shall the flame be snuffed out. Not as long as there is a sword and an arm to carry it. Non Nobis Domine!

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Non Nobis Domine!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cry is taken up. First by his three hundred, the men who have stood on Constantinople's walls for months, who have watched the city slowly die and wondered if anyone would ever come. Their voices crack with emotion. Then the rest—the veterans of Granada, the sailors turned soldiers, the men who followed Juan across the Mediterranean. Nine hundred voices rising together, swords lifted, the ancient words of the Templars echoing off stones that have not heard such a sound in centuries.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Seeds. Only seeds. But seeds are how forests begin.

roll.outcome: Solid response. Knights answer with proper fervor, Byzantines cautiously intrigued but guarded

encounters.recap: Juan addresses 915 assembled knights in Constantinople's ancient Hippodrome, acknowledging the monumental challenge ahead while rallying them with the crusader motto 'Non Nobis Domine.' The speech receives a solid response from the knights, while Byzantine onlookers remain cautiously hopeful but skeptical after centuries of Western betrayals.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The men will be settled by nightfall. Those from the walls know the city—they'll help the new arrivals find their footing. It is good to see you, sire. The men... we had begun to wonder if anyone remembered us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Royal Quarters — Early Evening. The armor comes off piece by piece. Servants assist—Byzantine attendants who handle the unfamiliar Castilian plate with careful hands. Juan's court clothes are laid out, brushed clean of travel dust.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The assembly. I could hear them from where I stood. Non Nobis Domine. The Byzantines watching—they wanted to believe. You could see it in their faces. They just... couldn't. Not yet.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor's Private Dining Chamber — Night. The room is small by imperial standards—intimate, even. A single table set for four: the Emperor, Juan, Lucia, and an empty place setting. John VIII rises as they enter. He has changed from his formal purple into simpler robes—still rich, but less ceremonial. His crown is absent. He looks... tired. Human.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: King Juan. Queen Lucia. Thank you for joining me. My wife sends her regrets. The Empress Maria is... unwell this evening. She hopes to meet you tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The food is simple but well-prepared—fish, bread, olives, wine. The plates are gold, ancient and beautiful, but there is not much on them. The empire's poverty extends even to the imperial table.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I watched your assembly from the walls. The Hippodrome has not heard such sounds in a very long time. You meant what you said. About not shying away from the truth.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So emperor, I have sent my men in advance, and also to deliver a message. That I see three main options for Constantinople. Refuge in Castille, share authority and fight with us, or give up nothing and fight alone. Has the emperor given these options thought?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I have given them thought. As has my council. As has the Patriarch, though he was not pleased to be consulted on such matters. Refuge in Castile. My family has held Constantinople for two centuries. Before us, other dynasties stretching back to Constantine. Eleven hundred years of Roman emperors. You ask me to consider becoming a guest in a foreign court. My children growing up speaking Castilian, forgetting Greek. The Palaiologos name becoming a curiosity, a relic, a bloodline that once meant something. And yet. My city starves. My walls crumble. My treasury is empty. My people look to me for salvation, and I have none to give. The third option—fight alone, preserve our pride, die on the walls. There is honor in it. The monks would approve. The Patriarch would bless us as we fell. But I have a son. And I find I am not yet ready to choose a glorious death over his future. Which leaves your second option. Share authority and fight together. What does that mean, King of Castile? Precisely?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me first put the refuge option in another perspective. What we could do is make you Duke of Grenada. I have put a governor in place after the crusade but have not given away the title yet. You and your family could live in the Alhambra, a palace that is maybe even more prestigeous than my own palace in Toledo. Your people can settle there, preserve your culture and language. You would be a duke serving me of course. But there is a real future in this. Now, in regards to the option of fighting. We must be careful in this regard. I understand that Constantinople is happy for any help offered, but I cannot and will not demand the Castillian sons to die for a lost cause. My thousand knights may only delay the inevitable, not turn the tide. In your opinion, what will turn the tide? What will be needed?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Duke of Granada. The Alhambra. Yes, I have heard of it. A Moorish palace of great beauty, taken by the king who now offers it as... compensation. For eleven centuries of Roman rule. You speak of your Castilian sons. Of not spending their lives on a lost cause. A wise king counts costs. I do not fault you for it. You ask me what will turn the tide. What will be needed. You are the king who conquered Granada in two years. Who reformed the Church. Who commands the respect of popes and princes. You have studied war. You have won wars. You have crossed the Mediterranean with a thousand knights to see this city with your own eyes. What do you think will be needed, King Juan? You have seen my walls. You have seen my treasury. You have seen my people. Tell me—what does the conqueror of Granada see when he looks at Constantinople?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have sailed across the seas and have lost one in ten of my best men to a storm. And even if I could just march my armies into Ottoman lands, even then could they field an army larger and better trained than what I can field. What I see when I look at the Byzantines is this: An old dying empire that is collapsing under the weight of it's once grand glory and prestige. Is everyone in your empire prepared to fight tooth and nail to drive the Ottomans out? Will the nobles, the clergy be prepared to consolidate power and unite in this purpose?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You ask if everyone is prepared to fight tooth and nail. No. The nobles. Some would fight. Others count their estates and calculate whether Ottoman rule might preserve their lands better than a war that could destroy everything. They whisper among themselves. They hedge. They send secret messages to the Sultan's court, testing the waters. The clergy. The Patriarch and his monks would rather see Constantinople fall than see it saved by Latin hands. They preach that union with Rome is worse than Turkish conquest. Better the Sultan's turban than the Pope's tiara. They say this from their monasteries while my soldiers die on the walls. And the people. The common people. They are tired, King Juan. Tired of war, tired of poverty, tired of emperors who promise salvation and deliver nothing. Some would fight. Others would open the gates tomorrow if it meant bread and peace. You ask if we are united. We are not. We have not been united in generations. That is the truth you came here to see. Now. Does that change your calculation?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If that is the case, how would you frame the question I would have to ask of Castillian sons who have to fight in a foreign land to conquer lands, increase the wealth of those who do not want to fight themselves?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I... You are asking me to justify... To explain why your sons should bleed for those who will not bleed for themselves. I have spent nine years seeking Western aid. Writing letters. Sending ambassadors. Promising union with Rome. Offering what little we have. I never once considered how those requests sounded to the men who would actually have to fight. I have no answer for you.

encounters.recap: At an intimate imperial dinner, Juan presents three options to Emperor John VIII: refuge in Castile as Duke of Granada, shared authority in fighting the Ottomans, or fighting alone. The Emperor admits the harsh truth about Byzantine disunity - nobles hedging bets with the Ottomans, clergy preferring Turkish rule to Roman union, and common people exhausted by war. When Juan questions why Castilian soldiers should die for those unwilling to fight for themselves, the Emperor confesses he has no answer, revealing the fundamental weakness of his position.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: I... You are asking me to justify... To explain why your sons should bleed for those who will not bleed for themselves. I have spent nine years seeking Western aid. Writing letters. Sending ambassadors. Promising union with Rome. Offering what little we have. I never once considered how those requests sounded to the men who would actually have to fight. I have no answer for you.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: If I were a Castilian soldier—young, strong, with a family waiting at home—and my king asked me to die for a city whose own people cannot agree whether it should be saved... I would ask why. So perhaps that is your answer, King Juan. Perhaps there is no answer. Perhaps Constantinople is already dead, and we are simply too proud to lie down. Unless you see something I do not.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: All you can do is offer people a choice. If they want to join the Sultan and be under muslim rule, that is their choice. We would have to drive the turks from lands that used to be Byzantine clay. If these lands would be returned to the empire, others would have been doing the fighting while all rewards go to you. That would simply be not fair. We would need to set up a strong alliance with rewards and titles to those risking their lives and who actually bled for it. And the nobles and the church would need to give up their privilege and be prepared to support this effort. The alternative is move the city to Grenada like I just mentioned. Or stay... but I will not. Can we put this choice before your empire? So that they may choose?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: Put this choice before my empire. You mean summon the nobles. The clergy. The people, perhaps. And tell them that Western aid comes with conditions. That those who fight will be rewarded with Byzantine lands. That those who do not fight will lose their privileges. That the alternative is exile or death. Do you know what would happen, King Juan? The nobles would rage. They would call it conquest dressed as alliance. They would say the Western king comes not to save Constantinople but to carve it up for his followers. Some of them would be right. The Patriarch would denounce it from every pulpit. He would say I am selling the empire to Catholic wolves. That I am betraying Orthodoxy, betraying our ancestors, betraying God himself. And the people... The people would be divided. Some would see hope. Others would see the final humiliation. You ask if we can put this choice before the empire. The question is not can we. The question is whether anything would survive the asking.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should come up with a complete plan on how this would look like. And if the Byzantines would regard it like betrayal and the Castillians would regard it like fighting for someone else at their own expense, then there is simply no saving the city and the empire.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: A complete plan. Very well. Let us speak plainly then, as men who have no time for courtly dances. You speak of rewards and titles for those who fight. Of nobles and clergy giving up privilege. But you have not yet said what Castile wants. What you want. You have crossed the Mediterranean. You have brought a thousand knights. You speak of driving the Turks from Byzantine lands. This is not charity, King Juan. No king spends such treasure, risks such lives, for nothing. If we are to build this plan together—if we are to present it to my nobles, my clergy, my people—then I must understand what shape it takes. What does Castile gain? What do you gain? Tell me what you see. This alliance, this... confederation of crowns. Where does Constantinople stand in it? Where does the Emperor stand?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: First of all, the 1000 knights and the 60.000 florins are a gift. I require nothing in return. Secondly, I do not require you to change religion. So no bowing down to the pope in Rome, you keep your religion such as it is. If ever the two churches want to come together, then it should be done out of genuine want, not out of desperation. Now, so far both the current situation and my offer of refuge in Castille. My question to Byzantine people is. Is there a problem? Do you require aid? Help to fight a fight you cannot win on your own. If the answer is that this is indeed the case, then I will take charge of the defence. That means no more hiding behind privilege and ancient agreement. Agreements that will be lost anyway when the city falls to the sultan. Whatever is left of the Byzantine empire will become part of the alliance between Aragon, Naples, Castille and Portugal. Only then will we be able to turn the tide. We in Iberia know what it is like to fight a reconquista and can teach you how to do the same. But if we are to bleed for someone else, we will only do so on our terms. So it means giving up pride and authority to let me lead the defence. I know that this is a difficult choice, but I want you to understand that this is not a demand at all. I offer you whatever I can give without asking for anything else in return. And consider the situation from our perspective and hopefully you and the others can see that I am sincere in what I offer. If you choose not to fight with us, then nothing is lost, everything I have given you stays here as a gift and my promise for refuge stays.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor does not respond immediately. He sits motionless, his hands flat on the table, staring at Juan. The fire crackles. The wine grows warm. Lucia watches in silence. When John VIII finally moves, it is to press his palms against his eyes. His shoulders tremble—just once. When he lowers his hands, his eyes are wet.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: All my life, I have waited for the West to save us. My father waited. His father waited. We sent ambassadors. We promised union with Rome. We debased ourselves before popes and princes who smiled and nodded and gave us nothing. And when aid did come—at Nicopolis, at Varna—it came with arrogance. Western knights who knew better than us. Who would not listen. Who charged to their deaths and called it glory while we buried the consequences. I stopped believing anyone would come. I told myself I was being realistic. Pragmatic. I was preparing my son for a future of slow surrender, of managing decline, of—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops. Turns. Looks at Juan with an expression stripped of all imperial dignity. Just a man. Exhausted. Desperate. And for the first time in years—hoping.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: You are not asking me to kneel. You are not asking me to betray my faith. You are offering me a choice. A real choice. No one has ever... You could have demanded anything. You hold all the strength. And instead you say—if you do not want this, we part as friends. I have been emperor for nine years. I have never once felt like I had a true ally. Advisors, yes. Servants. Sycophants. Men who wanted something. But you—you came here to see. To understand. To offer without demanding.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He releases Juan's arm and steps back.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_paleologus
exchanges.text: Tomorrow. We begin tomorrow. I will summon the nobles, the clergy, the garrison commanders. I will tell them what you have told me—the choice before us. And I will ask you to stand beside me when I do. Some will refuse. The Patriarch may denounce us both. Nobles will scheme and threaten. But for the first time in nine years, I know what I am fighting for. Not just survival. Not just delay. But a future my son might actually live to see. You asked what Constantinople needs to turn the tide. I did not answer. The answer is this. Someone who sees us as we are—broken, proud, failing—and still believes we are worth saving. Partners, King Juan. Not supplicant and savior. Partners.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will work together to give your people a choice. Now, it's time to draft a plan for the defence of the empire. I need scribes and advisors who know of the current actual and legal situation. Let me do my work emperor, and see how I would lead the defence of our kingdoms. Do you have a cabinet? Now is the time to summon them.

roll.outcome: Transformation. Something shifts fundamentally. The Emperor stops seeing this as surrender and starts seeing it as salvation. He commits fully, personally, and asks how they begin tomorrow.

encounters.recap: Juan presents his terms for defending Constantinople: he will take command of the defense while respecting Byzantine religion and offering unconditional gifts. After an emotional breakthrough, Emperor John VIII accepts the alliance, seeing Juan as the first genuine partner the empire has had. They agree to present the choice to Byzantine nobles and clergy tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Some will refuse. The Patriarch may denounce us both. Nobles will scheme and threaten. But for the first time in nine years, I know what I am fighting for. Not just survival. Not just delay. But a future my son might actually live to see.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: You asked what Constantinople needs to turn the tide. I did not answer. The answer is this. Someone who sees us as we are—broken, proud, failing—and still believes we are worth saving.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Partners, King Juan. Not supplicant and savior. Partners.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will work together to give your people a choice.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Now, it's time to draft a plan for the defence of the empire. I need scribes and advisors who know of the current actual and legal situation. Let me do my work emperor, and see how I would lead the defence of our kingdoms. Do you have a cabinet? Now is the time to summon them. Lucia, please stay by my side.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor clasps Juan's hand firmly. Something has changed in his bearing—the weariness remains, but beneath it now is purpose.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: A cabinet. What remains of one.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: You will have scribes. Maps. What records we possess. And you will have honesty. No more pretending we are stronger than we are.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, they have assembled in a larger room. A fire blazes. Candles flicker on every surface. A great table dominates the center, and servants are unrolling maps—old maps, their edges frayed, their ink faded, but still legible. The men who file in are few. The Emperor introduces them as they arrive: Loukas Notaras — Megas Doux, Grand Admiral and the wealthiest man in Constantinople. Perhaps fifty, sharp-eyed, dressed in robes finer than the Emperor's. Sphrantzes — already known to Juan. Demetrios Kantakouzenos — a military commander, grey-bearded, scarred, wearing worn armor even at this hour. Patriarch Joseph II — an unexpected addition. Ancient, frail, leaning on a cane.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: King Juan of Castile. He has come to help us plan our defense. And to understand our situation as it truly is.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: And what authority does the King of Castile hold in this planning?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: As you may know, I have already offered Constantinople aid as a gift. I ask nothing in return. And I foresee three choices before us.

encounters.recap: Emperor Constantine transforms from weary supplicant to determined partner, shaking hands with Juan on an alliance of equals. He summons his remaining cabinet members to meet in the war room, where Juan begins to assert his role as strategic advisor despite subtle challenges from the nobles, particularly Loukas Notaras questioning his authority.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor glances at the Patriarch but says nothing. The men arrange themselves around the table. Maps of Constantinople, the Bosphorus, Thrace, and Anatolia spread before them. The Emperor gestures to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: King Juan of Castile. He has come to help us plan our defense. And to understand our situation as it truly is.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: And what authority does the King of Castile hold in this planning?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: As you may know, I have already offered Constantinople aid as a gift. I ask nothing in return. And I foresee three choices before us. I shall provide shelter and refuge for the Byzantines in my kingdom. There you can live in peace and preserve your religion and culture. But it means leaving Constantinople. If you do not want that, I leave my gifts behind and sail away so the empire can sail its own course and maybe be absorbed by the Muslims. Tonight we are planning for the third option. An option that asks tremendous sacrifice both in blood and in pride. It is an option, mind you. Not a demand, rather a choice the Byzantine people should make. A choice with alternatives, for a choice without an alternative is no choice at all. I say this because I know that what I am about to plan for, may sound outlandish, maybe even insulting to the proud and prestigious people of the empire. I remind you again that we are planning for a choice, that this is not a demand. That I require authority not for personal gain or glory, but to unite everyone under one banner, one purpose. There simply is no time, space or room anymore for the old ways. We adapt or we die among ancient tradition. Now, firstly, Religion. Whatever will be discussed, the matter of the Filioque will not be. Now is not the time of religious reform or mending of the schism. That may come later if it will come at all. But I require nothing from the church except for the support both in holy service as in monetary terms as we all will have to pay. Secondly. I am in command. Me and only me. I will lead not just the defense of Constantinople, I will also have to lead the crowns of Naples, Aragon, Castile and Portugal in this fight and negotiate alliances with other christian kingdoms such as Hungary, Poland and the holy Roman empire. I have led a reconquista before and will do so again. Part of the choice is if the Byzantine people trust me with the leadership. Remember, I am not demanding, it is a choice. Thirdly, I will require you to fight like devils. No more hiding behind walls, titles or privilege. Christianity fights for your empire, and you will fight the hardest of all. I will militarize the nobility and arm every citizen. Trade, the church and science will be geared towards warfare. Everyone fights. Tonight we will draft proposals that detail in more specific terms what I have just laid out. So we can present this choice to the empire. After it has been presented, I will wait and will let you make a choice awaiting whatever you decide. You have been summoned to help me and the emperor in doing just this. Is everyone in this room ready to proceed?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence follows Juan's words. It stretches. The fire pops. A candle gutters.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: You are in command. You. A Western king who arrived this afternoon. Who has never walked our walls. Who does not speak our tongue. Who knows nothing of Ottoman tactics, nothing of our treaties, nothing of our situation. And you expect us to hand you everything? Our armies, our treasury, our nobility, our empire?

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: The Megas Doux speaks harshly, but he speaks truth. You say you demand nothing of the Church. You say the Filioque will not be discussed. Pretty words. But what you do demand is worse. You demand we place our faith—our survival—in a Latin king. A servant of the Pope, whatever you claim tonight. And when you have command of our armies, our walls, our people... what then? The Fourth Crusade came to help us as well. They burned our libraries. They stole our relics. They put a Latin patriarch in the Hagia Sophia for sixty years. And now another Westerner offers help. Offers choices. And we are to trust him?

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this is madness. We cannot hand our empire to a stranger on the basis of one dinner conversation. The nobles will never accept it. The people will riot. And when the Sultan hears that Constantinople has become a Castilian puppet—

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Enough. King Juan is our guest. He has come farther than any Western prince to—

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: To what? To conquer us with kindness instead of swords? The result is the same, Your Majesty. We become a province of Spain.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: I came tonight to hear this Western king for myself. I have heard enough.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Demand? Conquer and subjugate Constantinople? I have been warned for Byzantine pride before but I chose not to believe it. Father Patriarch, leave if you must but know that I do not like my words twisted. I have not demanded anything. I have only given aid and respect. Me not demanding the Byzantines to trust me is the entire point of a choice. You heard that I demand this trust tonight, but that was not what I said. Tonight we develop a plan and offer it as a choice to you all. Then you can take time to get to know me and for me to know you. No choice tonight or tomorrow but later when we are ready. And if you choose to go your own way, I will bless you, leave my 60,000 florins in your care. And I will bid you farewell as I sail back to my kingdom. All I ask of this council is to help shape this plan. To at least give this choice a chance. For the Byzantines to have the chance to make a choice in the first place. I buried almost 100 of my men on my way here. I cannot help but feel like their deaths have been in vain if we just give up now.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: One hundred men. Buried at sea. I do not doubt your sacrifice, King of Castile. I do not doubt your sincerity. But sincerity is not wisdom. And sacrifice does not confer the right to command. Many sincere men have led armies to destruction. Many sacrifices have been made in vain. I will not help shape a plan that places Constantinople under Latin authority. Not tonight. Not ever. If that is the only choice you offer, then we have nothing more to discuss.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: The Patriarch speaks for the Church. I speak for those who have wealth to lose. You ask us to give up everything on faith. Faith in a man we met today. Your Majesty, I have served your family for thirty years. I will not abandon you. But I will not endorse this proposal. Not as it stands. When the King of Castile has a plan that does not require us to become his subjects, I will listen. Until then...

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: That... could have gone better.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Patriarch will oppose anything that smells of Rome. He always has. Notaras will oppose anything that threatens his purse. But they have not said no. Not finally. They have said not yet. One hundred men buried at sea. My soldiers die on the walls every month. Fewer, but they die. I am not leaving this room, King of Castile. I want to hear your plan.

roll.outcome: Bitter stalemate. The Patriarch pauses but does not return. Notaras remains hostile. No progress, but no further deterioration. The meeting ends in cold silence.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a radical defense plan requiring complete Byzantine submission to his military command. The cabinet reacts with hostile rejection—Patriarch Joseph II and Loukas Notaras walk out, viewing the proposal as Western conquest disguised as aid. Despite Juan's emotional appeal about his 100 dead soldiers, only Kantakouzenos remains willing to continue planning. The meeting fractures but does not completely collapse.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Patriarch will oppose anything that smells of Rome. He always has. Notaras will oppose anything that threatens his purse. But they have not said no. Not finally. They have said not yet. One hundred men buried at sea. My soldiers die on the walls every month. Fewer, but they die. I am not leaving this room, King of Castile. I want to hear your plan.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We continue. Summon another senior captain who wants to cooperate with this planning session, and likewise summon someone who can speak of the church and it's politics and position. These two have excluded themselves from this planning session, we go on without them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor and Kantakouzenos exchange a glance. Kantakouzenos rubs his jaw. 'Another captain. I have men who would listen. Men who are tired of waiting to die. Alexios Philanthropenos. Commands the garrison at the Gate of Charisius—where your knights are quartered. He has worked alongside your Don Juan de Sotomayor. He respects the Castilians.' The Emperor's expression is more troubled. 'The Church is... more difficult. The Patriarch has made his position clear. Any priest who participates tonight without his blessing risks censure. Possibly excommunication.' Sphrantzes clears his throat. 'There is one possibility, Your Majesty. Father Gennadios. He is not senior—a scholar more than a politician. But he has written extensively on the question of Western relations. He believes union with Rome is heresy, yet he has also argued that Orthodoxy must find ways to survive, not merely remain pure while dying.' The Emperor frowns. 'Gennadios is... unpredictable.' 'He is honest,' Sphrantzes replies quietly. 'And he is not afraid of the Patriarch.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: An hour later, the fire has been rebuilt. Fresh candles burn. Wine and bread have been brought—working fuel for a long night. Two new men have joined the table. Alexios Philanthropenos — A lean man in his thirties, dark-bearded, wearing armor that has seen real use. He carries himself like a soldier who has stopped caring about politics and only wants clear orders. Father Gennadios Scholarios — Younger than expected, perhaps forty. Black robes, a scholar's ink-stained fingers, and eyes that burn with intelligence. He sits apart from the others, watching Juan like a man studying a theological problem.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Gentlemen. We are here to draft a plan—a proposal to present to our people. A choice. King Juan will explain what he envisions. Listen. Ask questions. Help us shape something that might actually work.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: I watched the Patriarch leave. I watched Notaras leave. You understand, King of Castile, that whatever we build tonight, those two will try to tear down tomorrow?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will draft a plan for victory. Then we will see. I will see. I explain to the new members of the council again what we are about to set up. And that it is a choice, not a demand.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan lays out the proposal again. The choice. The three options. The requirements for the third path—unified command, total mobilization, everyone fights. Philanthropenos listens with his arms folded, his dark eyes fixed on the maps. His expression betrays nothing. Gennadios sits with his ink-stained fingers steepled before his lips, watching Juan the way a theologian watches a disputant whose argument may contain hidden heresy.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: You say unified command. You say you command. I have four hundred men at the Gate of Charisius. Your Sotomayor has three hundred Castilians. Together, perhaps we could hold one section of the walls. Four miles of walls. Ninety-six towers. We would need ten thousand men to defend them properly. We have perhaps three thousand, including your knights. You speak of victory. Of driving back the Ottomans. With what? Where do these armies come from? How do they arrive before Murad decides the time has come?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: The military questions are for soldiers. I have others. You say you demand nothing of the Church. You say the Filioque will not be discussed. This is... appreciated. But you also say the Church must contribute. Monetary terms, you said. Holy service. What does this mean, precisely? The monasteries own lands. The Patriarch controls revenues. If you militarize the nobility and arm every citizen, what happens to Church properties? Church privileges? Church authority over its own affairs? I am not the Patriarch. I do not reject cooperation with the West on principle. But I must understand what I would be defending before I defend it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am glad you question me like this! To address the military ones first: We do indeed require not 2000 more soldiers, not even 10,000 more. I will seek to lead an alliance of over 100,000 troops from multiple corners of Christianity. Castille commands around 50,000 troops but with the aid of my alliance network, I am sure we are able to raise this number. Holding the walls is not our goal. We will drive them from the European continent and break them in the field. The time to cower behind walls is over. I have founded an academy in Toledo that studies Ottoman tactics and these 1000 knights have been trained using the most modern techniques and 10 junior officers are here as observers to later lead the armies that will be fighting the Ottomans. And regarding the spiritual side. I will militarize the church as well. Take inspiration from how the latin church has won the reconquista. Military orders of warrior monks who dedicate their lives to fighting the muslims. Churches blessing warriors and collect money to fund the effort. Crusades uniting churches and collect funds for these wars. Everyone fights. The church may not hold a sword, it fights in a different way.

roll.outcome: Cautious distance. They hear Juan out, ask probing questions, but make no commitments. The plan can be discussed, but trust is thin. Progress will be slow.

encounters.recap: After the Patriarch and Notaras storm out, Juan calls for replacement advisors. Two new men join the council: Captain Philanthropenos and Father Gennadios. Both listen cautiously to Juan's grand plan but raise pointed questions about military logistics and Church authority. The new council maintains polite distance, willing to discuss but making no firm commitments.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am glad you question me like this! To address the military ones first: We do indeed require not 2000 more soldiers, not even 10,000 more. I will seek to lead an alliance of over 100,000 troops from multiple corners of Christianity. Castile commands around 50,000 troops but with the aid of my alliance network, I am sure we are able to raise this number. Holding the walls is not our goal. We will drive them from the European continent and break them in the field. The time to cower behind walls is over. I have founded an academy in Toledo that studies Ottoman tactics and these 1000 knights have been trained using the most modern techniques and 10 junior officers are here as observers to later lead the armies that will be fighting the Ottomans. And regarding the spiritual side. I will militarize the church as well. Take inspiration from how the Latin church has won the reconquista. Military orders of warrior monks who dedicate their lives to fighting the Muslims. Churches blessing warriors and collect money to fund the effort. Crusades uniting churches and collect funds for these wars. Everyone fights. The church may not hold a sword, it fights in a different way.

exchanges.speaker: katakolon_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: One hundred thousand. I have fought the Ottomans for fifteen years. I have seen what they bring to the field. Discipline. Janissaries who do not break. Sipahi cavalry that flows like water around any formation. One hundred thousand Christians, united under one command, fighting as one army... If you could deliver such a thing, it would be the greatest host Christendom has assembled since the First Crusade. But how? Castile is far. Aragon is entangled in Italy. Portugal faces Africa. Hungary bleeds against the Turks already. Poland looks east to the steppe. I do not doubt your ambition, King of Castile. But ambition is not soldiers. Where do these hundred thousand men come from? When do they arrive? And what holds them together when they are here?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: Military orders. Warrior monks. The Templars. The Hospitallers. Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara. The Latin church created these orders over centuries. They answered to the Pope. They held vast lands, vast wealth. They became powers unto themselves—until kings and popes destroyed them for that very reason. You propose to create such orders for the Orthodox church. In months, not centuries. Without papal authority to bind them. Without lands to sustain them. And you expect the monasteries—who have guarded their independence for a thousand years—to simply... transform themselves into soldiers? I do not say it is impossible. I say I do not understand how you imagine it would work. The monks of Mount Athos would sooner burn their monasteries than take up swords. The Patriarch would excommunicate any priest who blessed such an order without his sanction. You speak of everyone fighting. But the Church fights with prayer, with teaching, with the preservation of sacred truth. If you wish to change that—if you wish Orthodox monks to become Latin-style warrior orders—you must explain how. And you must explain who would lead them, fund them, command them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Gennadios, yes yes, very good. But again, do not twist my words. I said TAKE INSPIRATION from the Latin church. Not copy it. You are here exactly because we need to figure out what this would look like in the Orthodox tradition. Otherwise I could ask any of my Catholic priests instead. Tonight we will ask ourselves: 'If the Orthodox church would turn every effort into winning this war, what would that look like?' Can you help us answer that question Gennadios? And regarding the soldiers we do not have: Yes, I cannot snap my fingers and summon the Polish king into this room. We do not know what moves them. We hope to invite them into an alliance and attack the Ottomans together. That is why the structure we set up is so important. If I meet with them, I have the authority to bind the entire alliance. And that there is a structure that fighting the Ottomans actually is rewarded. The structure would be something like this: The kingdoms of Naples, Aragon, Castile and perhaps Portugal enter into a strong alliance of crowns. My family sits on these thrones so I hold much direct control over them already. Any lands taken from the Ottomans will be distributed using the crusade system. The reconquista, a concept familiar to the Iberians. The Poles and the Hungarians already border the Ottomans. I think it will not take much to convince them to attack with us. But only if we are serious about attacking them and the Ottomans are seriously occupied. That is why the structure is so important. If we attack them from all sides, Hungary and Poland gain lands and they press forward and what was once Greek lands will be reconquered. We may yet lose. We may yet be defeated. But if we have a good plan and the Byzantines choose to fight, I think we should.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: If the Orthodox church would turn every effort into winning this war. What would that look like. The monasteries hold wealth. Lands. Gold. Relics that pilgrims pay to venerate. They could tithe for war. They have done so before, in centuries past, when emperors demanded it. The Patriarch would resist, but if the people believed the cause was holy... The monks will not become knights. That is not our tradition. But they could support knights. Pray for them. Bless them. Tend their wounded. Copy their letters. Preserve their names for history. The monasteries were fortresses once, in darker times. Some still have walls. They could shelter refugees, store supplies, serve as waypoints. And there is this: we have priests who fight. Not officially. Not with the Patriarch's blessing. But village priests who took up swords against raiders. Monks who died on the walls in sieges past. The tradition exists, even if we do not speak of it. If you want the Orthodox church to fight—truly fight—you do not create military orders. You create a holy cause. A crusade in all but name. You have the Emperor proclaim that the defense of Constantinople is sacred duty. You have priests preach it from every pulpit. You have monks process through the streets with icons and relics, blessing the soldiers, cursing the enemy. The Patriarch would hate it. But if the people believed... the Patriarch would have to follow or be swept aside.

exchanges.speaker: katakolon_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Multi-front war. Press them from all sides. Sound strategy. The Ottomans are strong, but they cannot be everywhere. If Hungary strikes while we hold the straits, if Poland threatens their northern vassals... But timing is everything. If we attack before the others are ready, we die alone. If they attack before we are ready, they die alone. How do you coordinate armies separated by a thousand miles? How do you ensure the Hungarians do not make peace the moment they have taken what they want? I have seen alliances. They promise much. They deliver little. Each king thinks first of his own lands, his own glory. What makes this different? What binds them?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Once we have proven we are a serious challenge to the Ottomans, I can let greed do much of the work. If the Ottomans are challenged near Constantinople, soon, the kings of Poland and Hungary will see that the lands bordering them will be easy prey. It requires us to take up the sword first and they will not move until they have seen us match the Turks in the field and will. But once we have, they will not be able to defend their northern border. Greed is a powerful ally. But we will have to stand on our own first, I have no doubt about it. That is why our plan is so important. We build up our strength, and sooner or later, others will descend on them as well.

exchanges.speaker: katakolon_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Greed. Yes. I have seen what greed does to alliances. It can tear them apart. But it can also bind them, if there is enough to go around. There is enough. If we truly threatened them, there would be enough for everyone. Hungary wants Serbia back. Poland eyes the Black Sea coast. Venice wants its trading posts secure. Genoa... Genoa wants whatever Venice does not have. You say we must prove ourselves first. Match them in the field. With what we have now—your thousand, my few thousand, the walls—we cannot meet them in open battle. We would be slaughtered. But. If we hold. If we bleed them at the walls. If we make the price too high... Murad is not a fool. He will not spend fifty thousand men to take a city he could starve into submission. If we show him that Constantinople will cost more than it is worth—that is how we buy time. Time for your alliances to form. Time for greed to do its work.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: A holy cause. Time. And greed. These are not inspiring words for a sermon. But they are honest. You ask what the Orthodox church would look like if it turned every effort to war. I begin to see the shape of it. First—a proclamation. The Emperor declares the defense of Constantinople sacred duty. Not union with Rome. Not submission. Simply: this is holy work. Second—the monasteries tithe. Not their lands. Not their independence. But gold. Grain. Medicine. Whatever they can spare. Those who refuse... We shame them. Publicly. Let the people see who hoards while soldiers die. Third—processions. Icons. Relics carried through the streets. The Virgin of Blachernae—she has saved this city before. The people must believe this fight is blessed. I cannot promise the Patriarch's support. But I can promise this: if the people believe, the Patriarch will follow. He is old. He fears being left behind more than he fears the Latins.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: We have talked through half the night. Dawn is not far. Do we have enough to put before the nobles? Before the people? A proposal—a choice—that they can accept or reject?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us have a good night's sleep. Tomorrow, we meet again at midday and we continue with the nobles. We ask ourselves the question, what would it look like if the nobles turn every effort into winning the war. And then the burghers, the guilds, the commoners. And then... I think a plan for victory starts to take shape. But let us sleep on it for now. We continue tomorrow.

roll.outcome: Strong strategic framework emerges. Orthodox church mobilization path identified, multi-front alliance strategy clarified, greed-based incentive structure accepted.

encounters.recap: The strategic cabinet session reaches breakthrough consensus on Byzantine defense strategy. Gennadios outlines how Orthodox church can mobilize without becoming military orders—through tithes, processions, and declaring defense a sacred duty. Philanthropenos accepts the multi-front alliance concept but emphasizes Constantinople must prove itself first by bleeding the Ottomans at the walls to demonstrate serious resistance before other kingdoms will join. Juan's strategy of leveraging greed to bind allies is acknowledged as realistic. The session concludes with plans to continue developing the framework with nobles, guilds, and commoners.
